cs.CL, cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.NE, cs.IR. 

This paper proposes a neural framework for sentence-level discourse analysis, which falls under the category of natural language processing (NLP). Specifically, the paper focuses on Rhetorical Structure Theory (RST), which is a well-established framework in NLP. Therefore, the most likely category is cs.CL (Computation and Language), which is dedicated to NLP and its related fields. 

The paper also mentions that their framework is based on Pointer Networks, which is a type of neural network architecture. This suggests that the paper may also be relevant to the sub-categories of cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) and cs.LG (Machine Learning). 

Furthermore, the paper reports performance metrics for their framework, indicating that it involves some form of optimization or training. This suggests that the paper may also be relevant to the sub-categories of cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing) and cs.IR (Information Retrieval), which both involve optimization and learning techniques.
